metadata.title: Direct hydrodeoxygenation and hydrogenation of 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylphenol over sulphided CoMo catalyst

Geverta,*, M. Erikssona,1, P. Erikssona,l, F.E. Massothb 'Department of Engineering Chemistry, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Gothenburg, Sweden 'Department of Chemical and Fuels Engineering, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah 84112, USA Received 11 January 1994; revised 13 May 1994; accepted 24 May 1994 Abstract Hydrodeoxygenatiop of 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylphenol (DMP) over a sulphided CoMo/alumina catalyst was carried out at 5 MPa HZ pressure and over a temperature range of 240 to 330. For 3,5-DMP, the major reaction product was m-xylene, whereas for 2,6-DMP, about equal amounts of m-xylene and 1,3-dimethylcyclohexane were obtained. The reaction is considered to proceed through two pathways: (1) direct cleavage of the C(aromatic)-0bond leading to an aromatic product; and (2) prehydrogenation of the phenol ring, followed by rapid C(aliphatic)-0 rupture leading to a saturated cyclic compound. For path (1), 2,6-DMP was approximately ten times less reactive than 3,5-DMP, which was explained in terms of steric hindrance to adsorption by the methyl groups adjacent to the OH group. For path (2), 3,5-DMP was more reactive than 2,6-DMP at temperatures below 290, but less reactive above this temperature. The latter results were interpreted in terms of differences in delocalized resonance effects, in which adsorption and intrinsic hydrogenation reactivity compete in opposite directions to yield the different global rates versus temperature. Keywords: Direct hydrodeoxygenation; Dimethylphenols; HDO; Hydrogenation; Hydrogenolysis; Sulphided CoMo catalyst 1. Introduction Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) has received much attention during the last ten years because oxygen compounds are present in synthetic fuels obtained from coal, peat, and biomass. Of importance among these are phenolic compounds. Several * Corresponding author. E-mail: borje.gevert@tk.chalmers.se, tel. ( +46-31)7721000, fax. ( +46-31)160062. ' Present address: Nynas Petroleum, S-149 82 Nynashamn, Sweden. 0926-860X/94/$07.00 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSDI0926-860X(94)00114-7 152 S.B. Gevert et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 117 (1994)151-162 groups have recently reported basic studies of the HDO of model compound phenols [ 1-6 ] . Sulphided CoMo and NiMo catalysts are efficient catalysts for HDO [ 7 ] . It is known that phenols can react in two different ways under hydrogen pressure and sulphided CoMo catalysts. The first reaction is direct deoxygenation of the phenol without saturation of the aromatic ring and the second is hydrogenation of the aromatic ring before deoxygenation. In this paper, we present the kinetics of the hydrodeoxygenation of two dimethyl substituted phenols. The results are used to interpret the nature of the active sites on the catalyst involved during the hydrodeoxygenation pathways. 2. Experimental The experimental methods have been reported in detail elsewhere [ 6 ] . Briefly, the catalyst studied contained 15% M003 and 4.2% CoO on -t-alumina (Ketjen KF 742) . The catalyst 0.3 to 2 g was presulphided with hydrogen sulphide (10%) in hydrogen in a separate reactor at 400. The phenol was dissolved in cetane (0.144 mol/1) and added to a 300 cm3 autoclave with a magnetic drive stirrer. The sulphided catalyst was added to the phenol solution with minimum exposure to air. Hydrogen was added to about 2 MPa and heating was applied to the reaction temperature. At temperature, stirring was started and pressure adjusted to 5.0 MPa. Periodic samples were withdrawn for analysis by GC-FID. Reaction products consisted of m-xylene, dimethylcyclohexane and smaller amounts of dimethylcyclohexenes. The isomers of the latter were not specifically identified. Their amounts were added to the dimethylcyclohexane to give the hydrogenated product. 3. Results 3.1. Reaction pathways In Fig. 1 the course of an experiment with 3,5-dimethylphenol (3,5-DMP) is presented. The amounts of dimethylcyclohexane and m-xylene increase proportionally throughout the run, indicative of the parallel reaction paths for these products. The product hydrogenation selectivity plot of Fig. 2 (hydrogenated vs. aromatic products) shows a good linear relationship, further demonstrating the two parallel pathways. It is noted that the aromatic yield is some seven times greater than the hydrogenated products. From the above results, the kinetic reaction network of Fig. 3 is proposed, which is in principal the same as previously proposed for monomethyl-substituted phenols [ 6 ] . S.B. Gevert et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 117 (1994)151-162 3.2. Reaction kinetics 153 At low conversion, reactions (1) and (2) dominate, but at higher conversions, when the amount of dimethylphenol is low and the amount of xylene is high, reaction (3) becomes important. In the subsequent kinetic analysis, only data at relatively short times are used to calculate rate constants, i.e. reaction path (3) is negligible. 0.8- 0.s m o 2 0.4 0.2- 0 0.2 0.4 0.8 0.8 1 f(t/V) Fo.12 0.04 0 Fig. 1. Gevert et al. l Applied Catalysis A: General 117 (1994)151-162 where k is the global rate constant and X the mole fraction. These equations are strictly valid only for a constant volume system, and must be modified to account for loss of solution volume due to sampling. To account for this we introduce a function f(tlV)=F,i(t;-t;-1)I V;} where tj _ 1 to tl is the time interval during which the solution volume is constant at Vj. The derivation of f(tl V) is presented in the Appendix. Application to Eq. (1) leads to -In X= (kl +k2)Wf(tlV) where W is catalyst weight. Thus, kl plus k2 can be obtained by plotting - In XA vs. f(tl V). Such a plot of the data of Fig. 1 is given in Fig. 4, which demonstrates good conformance to first-order reaction. Combination of Eqs. (2) and (3) gives k2lk1 =XcIXB (6) which is equal to the slope of Fig. 2. Thus, individual values of k can be calculated. In Table 1, average first-order rate constants for 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylphenols are presented. The fit of the data from these parameters is illustrated by the lines on Fig. 1, where a satisfactory agreement is seen. The position of the methyl group strongly affects the overall rate of disappearance of the phenol. The overall rate constant (kl+k2) is larger for methyl groups in the 3,5 position. This effect is mostly reflected in the rate constant for reaction (1) i.e. k, is some ten times greater for 3,5-DMP than for 2,6-DMP. Fig. 5 shows Arrhenius plots of the individual kl and k2 values for all runs, and apparent activation energies and pre-exponential factors are given in Table 2. Apparent activation energies for formation of aromatic products [ via path (1) ] are essentially identical for both DMP compounds, and are higher than for hydrogenated products [via path (2) ] . The apparent activation energy and pre-exponential factor for k2 (3,5) are considerably lower than for k2 (2,6), with the result that k2 [ reaction via path (2) ] is higher for 3,5-DMP below about 290, but lower above this temperature. 4. Discussion The results of this study are in agreement with other studies [ 1, 5, 6] , which show that ring saturation is not a prerequitite to the HDO of phenols, and support the idea that two different pathways are operative. In path (1), direct C(aromatic)O hydrogenolysis occurs leading to an aromatic product. In path (2), the ratelimiting step is hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, which is followed by rapid C (aliphatic) -0 hydrogenolysis leading to a saturated product. The high apparent activation energies found for path (1) are in agreement with the expected higher S.B. Gevert et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General]] 7 (1994)151-162 157 Table 3 Kinetic dimensions for adsorption of dimethylphenols Methyl End on Flatwise position D" position LX Wb 3,5 6.1 7.2 X 8.2 2,6 8.2 7.2 X 8.2 " D=Diameter in A; diameter of a S vacancy is 3.2 A. L=dimension along oxygen axis in A; W= longest width perpendicular to oxygen axis in A. activation energy of C (aromatic)-O bond rupture as compared with aromatic hydrogenation. Moreau and Geneste [ 8 ] have reviewed the factors affecting the reactivity of heteroatom model compounds and conclude that two sites are involved, viz. (1) a HYD site having an electron-withdrawing character, in which the reactant is adsorbed flatwise through the 7r-system and, (2) a hydrogenolysis site having an electron-donating character, in which the reactant is adsorbed vertically through the heteroatom. We have earlier proposed [6] for the reaction of phenols that two different reaction site centers are responsible for the two pathways, viz., a HDO site on which the phenol is adsorbed via the oxygen atom, and a HYD site on which the phenol is adsorbed flatwise through 7r-bonding of the aromatic ring. Current opinion is that sulphur vacancies are active sites for the reaction [ 9 ] , and these occur at edge positions of the two-dimensional slabs of the MOS2 phase [ 10] . Bonding of the phenol to the active sites must occur on the metal sites exposed by sulphur vacancies. 4.1. Hydrogenolysis (HDO) reactivities Reactivity of 3,5-DMP for direct C-0 bond cleavage by path (1), i.e. C-O bond hydrogenolysis, is about ten times greater than that of 2,6-DMP at all temperatures. These results are in agreement with those of Weigold [ 1 ] . We envision C-0 bond hydrogenolysis to occur by reaction of the adsorbed species with active adsorbed H or SH. Evidence for the latter has been reported [ 11-13 ] . Tracer studies [ 14 ] have shown that adsorbed hydrogen associated with SH groups take part in the C-S hydrogenolysis (HDS) of thiophene. Furthermore, the HDS reactivity of 4,6-dimethyl dibenzothiophene has been shown to be onetenth of that of dibenzothiophene [ 15 ] , which has been attributed to steric hindrance of the methyl groups adjacent to the S atom to adsorption of the S atom on the catalyst. The HDO of phenols may be considered analogous. In such a case, steric hindrance to adsorption due to the proximity of the methyl group to the OH group, could be an important factor in C-0 hydrogenolysis. Table 3 presents data of kinetic estimated dimensions for end-on adsorption through the oxygen atom of 158 S. B. Gevert et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 117 (1994)151-162 the DMP. For a sulphur vacancy equivalent to the diameter of an S2- ion, i.e. 3.2 A, it is seen that 3,5-DMP can be accommodated by two sulphur vacancies, whereas 2,6-DMP requires a three-vacancy site. Thus, the considerably lower reactivity of the 2,6-DMP may be due to exclusion from dual-vacancy sites, being confined to triple-vacancy sites, which are less plentiful. Therefore, steric hindrance effects may account for the large differences in hydrogenolysis activities. 4.2. Hydrogenation (HYD) reactivities Activities of 3,5- and 2,6-DMP for HYD [path (2) ] vary differently with temperature (Fig. 5), 3,5-DMP being higher below 290, and lower above this temperature. Steric hindrance effects cannot explain these results. Table 3 gives geometric requirements for flatwise adsorption of the dimethylphenols, assuming the whole molecule must fit into a multi-vacancy site center in order to approach the underlying Mo or Co atoms. The resultant areas are virtually identical for the two molecules, indicating that no steric effects should be expected for flatwise adsorption of either DMP. Aubert et al. [ 16] have also demonstrated that the hydrogenation of substituted phenols is not affected by steric hindrance. Therefore, we are led to consider possible electronic effects. The global rate constant k2 is given by k2 =k2jn2 (7) where k2j is the rate constant per active site and n2 is the number of active sites of type 2 per gram of catalyst. Adopting Langmuir-Hinschelwood kinetics, k2j -k2K2 (8) where k2 is the intrinsic rate constant and K2 is the adsorption equilibrium constant on type-2 adsorption sites. The temperature dependency of these constants is given by 02 =AZ exp(-E2RT) (9) K2 =K2 exp(Q2/RT) (10) where E2 is the true activation energy for reaction and Q2 is the heat of adsorption. Therefore, the apparent activation energy is related to the true activation energy by Ea,2=E2-Q2 (11) Assuming the same E2 for 3,5- and 2,6-DMP, i.e. the position of the methyl groups does not affect the intrinsic HYD reactivity, and since Ea,2(2,6) >Ea,2(3,5), then Q2(3,5) > Q2(2,6) (12) Thus, the heat of adsorption of 3,5-DMP will be greater than for 2,6-DMP. In a like manner, from Eqs. (8)-(10), the apparent preexponential factor Aa is given by S.B. Gevert et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General]] 7 (1994)151-162 159 Aa,2 =AOK (13) Now KZ is related to the adsorption per reaction site. Assuming this is unaffected by the position of the methyl groups, as adsorption is flatwise, and since Aa,2(2,6) >Aa,2(3,5), then Az(2,6) >A?(3,5) (14) i.e. the reactivity preexponential factor is larger for 2,6-DMP. Eqs. (12) and (14) provide a possible explanation for the different k2 Arrhenius plots of Fig. 5 for 2,6- and 3,5-DMP. The global rate constant, k2, is the product of an intrinsic reactivity parameter kz and an adsorption parameter K2. For 2,6-DMP, k2 increases with temperature faster than 3,5-DMP, while K2 decreases slower with temperature. These effects may be rationalized through electronic effects of the position of the methyl groups. Moreau et al. [ 17] have proposed that the hydrogenation of the benzene ring is related to the resonance of the ring, and have correlated their results for a series of mono-substituted aromatic compounds with a delocalized resonance parameter. According to Pross et al. [ 18], the effect of a second electron-donating group on phenol is to increase the ring resonance for a meta-substituent and to decrease it for an ortho-substituent. Since methyl groups are electron donor groups, then 3,5-DMP, having methyl groups meta to the OH group, will exhibit greater delocalized resonance. This higher aromaticity may result in a higher adsorption strength and a lower intrinsic activity towards hydrogenation, in accordance with the above analysis. It is noted that Moreau et al. [ 17] have proposed that direct hydrogenolysis of benzene substituted with various heteroatom groups (including OH) is also correlated by a resonance factor. Thus, our HDO hydrogenolysis rates may also have been influenced by an electronic factor. However, this would only have a relatively small effect on hydrogenolysis rates compared to the large effect observed. It is also noted that the activation energies of hydrogenolysis are the same for both compounds, which would not be expected if significant differences in electronic effects were present. Therefore, it is concluded that steric hindrance is the predominant factor influencing the hydrogenolysis reaction of 2,6-dimethylphenol. 5. Conclusions The HDO of dimethyl-substituted phenols is suggested to proceed through two pathways: (1) direct cleavage of the C(aromatic)-0 bond leading to an aromatic product; and (2) prehydrogenation of the phenol ring, followed by rapid C (aliphatic) -0 bond rupture leading to a saturated cyclic product. The reaction rate via path (1) is predominantly affected by steric hindrance of methyl groups 160 S.B. Gevert et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 117 (1994)151-162 adjacent to the OH group, whereas the rate of path (2) appears to be influenced by differences in delocalized resonance effects with the position of the methyl groups. Acknowledgement The authors are grateful for experimental help from Olivier Pataut. Financial support from the Chalmers Research Fund and from the Swedish National Board of Energy (Nutek) are appreciated. Appendix Kinetics for the reaction in a batch reactor when the volume changes due to sampling. The design equation for a batch reactor is -dNA/dt=WrA where NA is the moles of reactant A in the reactor at time, t, W is catalyst weight, and rA is the reaction rate. For a first-order reaction, rA = WA (A2) where k is the rate constant and CA is the concentration of A. Direct hydrodeoxygenation and hydrogenation of 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylphenol over sulphided CoMo catalyst S.B. Gevert * a M. Eriksson a 1 P. Eriksson a 1 F.E. Massoth b a Department of Engineering Chemistry, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Gothenburg, Sweden b Department of Chemical and Fuels Engineering, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah 84112, USA * Corresponding author. tel. (+46-31)7721000, fax. (+46-31) 160062. 1 Present address: Nyna¨s Petroleum, S-149 82 Nyna¨shamn, Sweden. Hydrodeoxygenation of 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylphenol (DMP) over a sulphided CoMo/alumina catalyst was carried out at 5 MPa H2 pressure and over a temperature range of 240°C to 330°C. For 3,5-DMP, the major reaction product wasm-xylene, whereas for 2,6-DMP, about equal amounts ofm-xylene and 1,3-dimethylcyclohexane were obtained. The reaction is considered to proceed through two pathways: (1) direct cleavage of the C(aromatic)-O bond leading to an aromatic product; and (2) prehydrogenation of the phenol ring, followed by rapid C(aliphatic)-O rupture leading to a saturated cyclic compound. For path (1), 2,6-DMP was approximately ten times less reactive than 3,5-DMP, which was explained in terms of steric hindrance to adsorption by the methyl groups adjacent to the OH group. For path (2), 3,5-DMP was more reactive than 2,6-DMP at temperatures below 290°C, but less reactive above this temperature. The latter results were interpreted in terms of differences in delocalized resonance effects, in which adsorption and intrinsic hydrogenation reactivity compete in opposite directions to yield the different global rates versus temperature. coredata.dc:description: Hydrodeoxygenation of 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylphenol (DMP) over a sulphided CoMo/alumina catalyst was carried out at 5 MPa H2 pressure and over a temperature range of 240°C to 330°C. For 3,5-DMP, the major reaction product wasm-xylene, whereas for 2,6-DMP, about equal amounts ofm-xylene and 1,3-dimethylcyclohexane were obtained. The reaction is considered to proceed through two pathways: (1) direct cleavage of the C(aromatic)-O bond leading to an aromatic product; and (2) prehydrogenation of the phenol ring, followed by rapid C(aliphatic)-O rupture leading to a saturated cyclic compound. For path (1), 2,6-DMP was approximately ten times less reactive than 3,5-DMP, which was explained in terms of steric hindrance to adsorption by the methyl groups adjacent to the OH group. For path (2), 3,5-DMP was more reactive than 2,6-DMP at temperatures below 290°C, but less reactive above this temperature. The latter results were interpreted in terms of differences in delocalized resonance effects, in which adsorption and intrinsic hydrogenation reactivity compete in opposite directions to yield the different global rates versus temperature.
coredata.dc:title: Direct hydrodeoxygenation and hydrogenation of 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylphenol over sulphided CoMo catalyst
